contentrichtext.text: {{chembox | verifiedrevid = 476996415 | Name = Oxaloacetic acid | ImageFile_Ref = {{chemboximage|correct|??}} | ImageFile = Oxaloacetic acid.png | ImageSize = 170px | ImageName = Skeletal structure | ImageFile1 = Oxaloacetic-acid-3D-balls.png | ImageName1 = Ball-and-stick model | IUPACName = Oxobutanedioic acid | OtherNames = Oxaloacetic acid<br />Oxalacetic acid<br />Oxosuccinic acid | Section1 = {{Chembox Identifiers | PubChem = 970 | StdInChI_Ref = {{stdinchicite|correct|chemspider}} | StdInChI = 1S/C4H4O5/c5-2(4(8)9)1-3(6)7/h1H2,(H,6,7)(H,8,9) | StdInChIKey_Ref = {{stdinchicite|correct|chemspider}} | StdInChIKey = KHPXUQMNIQBQEV-UHFFFAOYSA-N | CASNo_Ref = {{cascite|correct|CAS}} | CASNo = 328-42-7 | ChemSpiderID_Ref = {{chemspidercite|correct|chemspider}} | ChemSpiderID = 945 | EINECS = 206-329-8 | ChEBI_Ref = {{ebicite|correct|EBI}} | ChEBI = 30744 | SMILES = O=C(O)C(=O)CC(=O)O }} | Section2 = {{Chembox Properties | Formula = C<sub>4</sub>H<sub>4</sub>O<sub>5</sub> | MolarMass = 132.07 g/mol | MeltingPt = 161 째C | Density = ? g/cm<sup>3</sup> }} | Section4 = {{Chembox Thermochemistry | DeltaHf = -943.21 kJ/mol | DeltaHc = -1205.58 kJ/mol }} }} '''Oxaloacetic acid''' (also '''oxalacetic acid''') is an [[organic compound]] with the chemical formula C<sub>4</sub>H<sub>4</sub>O<sub>5</sub> or HOOC-(C=O)-(CH<sub>2</sub>)-COOH. It also has other names (see the table). Its fully [[deprotonation|deprotonated]] derivative is the '''oxaloacetate''' anion, C<sub>4</sub>H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>5</sub><sup>2−</sup> or [(COO-)(CH<sub>2</sub>)C=O(COO-)]<sup>2−</sup>; this name is also used for [[esters]] that contain the [[Valence (chemistry)|divalent]] [-O(C=O)<sub>2</sub>(CH<sub>2</sub>)(C=O)O-] [[Functional group|moiety]]. Loss of a single proton gives the acid's [[conjugate base]], the anion '''hydrogenoxaloacetate''' anion H(C=O)<sub>2</sub>(CH<sub>2</sub>)(C=O)<sup>−</sup>. ==Function== This four-[[carbon]] [[dicarboxylic acid]] is a [[protonation|protonated]] variant of oxaloacetate, which is an intermediate of the [[citric acid cycle]]<ref name="urlCitric Acid Cycle Reactions">{{cite web |url=http://www.elmhurst.edu/~chm/vchembook/611citricrx.html |title=Citric Acid Cycle Reactions |work= |accessdate=2009-04-18}}</ref> and [[gluconeogenesis]]. Oxaloacetate forms upon [[oxidation]] of L-[[Malic acid|malate]], catalysed by [[malate dehydrogenase]], and reacts with [[Acetyl-CoA]] to form [[citrate]], catalysed by [[citrate synthase]]. It also forms in the [[Leaf#Mesophyll|mesophyll]] of plants by the condensation of [[Carbon dioxide|CO<sub>2</sub>]] with [[phosphoenolpyruvate]], catalysed by [[Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase|PEP Carboxykinase]]<!--carboxykinase???? Are you sure? I think it is carboxylase-->. It can arise from [[pyruvate]] via an [[anaplerotic reactions|anaplerotic reaction]]. Oxaloacetate is also a potent inhibitor of [[Complex II]]. [[Image:Oxaloac-malic.png|thumb|150px|center|Relationship of oxaloacetic acid, malic acid, and aspartic acid]] ==Chemical properties== The [[enol]] forms of oxaloacetic acid are particularly stable, so much so that the two isomers have different melting points (152 째C for the ''cis'' isoform and 184 째C for the ''trans'' isoform). The enol proton has a [[Acid dissociation constant|pK<sub>a</sub> value]] of 13.02. Oxaloacetate is unstable in solution, decomposing to pyruvate by [[decarboxylation]] over a period of hours (room temperature) or days (0 째C).<ref>http://www.sigmaaldrich.com/etc/medialib/docs/Sigma/Product_Information_Sheet/2/o4126pis.Par.0001.File.tmp/o4126pis.</ref> Refrigerated storage of the solid is therefore recommended. == Interactive pathway map == {| |width=390|{{GlycolysisGluconeogenesis_WP534|highlight=Oxaloacetic_acid}} |width=390|{{TCACycle_WP78|highlight=Oxaloacetic_acid}} |} ==See also== *[[dioxosuccinic acid]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{citric acid cycle}} {{Amino acid metabolism intermediates}} [[Category:Citric acid cycle compounds]] [[Category:Dicarboxylic acids]] [[Category:Keto acids]]
